docs.lead_paragraph: Updated In a new e-mail letter, Tim Kaine, the head of the Democratic National Committee, asks supporters to pledge $5 or more to help defend lawmakers from the threats they've reported after the health care bill passed over the weekend.

headline.main: The Early Word: Back to the House

docs.lead_paragraph: Voters to Decide on Legalizing Marijuana | For the second time in 40 years, voters in California will decide whether to legalize marijuana, after a ballot initiative -- which proposes to legalize pot and allow it to be sold and taxed -- qualified to be on the November ballot, state officials announced Wednesday. Supporters turned in 694,248 signatures from every county except Alpine. Officials in Los Angeles County, where the signatures were submitted Wednesday night, estimated 523,531 signatures were valid. To qualify for the November election, the ballot needed 433,971 signatures. Richard Lee, an Oakland marijuana entrepreneur, has spent $1.3 million to put together the campaign. "We're one step closer to ending cannabis prohibition and the unjust laws that lock people up for cannabis while alcohol is not only sold openly but advertised on television to kids every day," he said. [The Los Angeles Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline.main: Sampler: Voters to Decide on Legalizing Marijuana, and the Mud Claims a Ghost Town

docs.lead_paragraph: When the city of Los Angeles started looking into its complex financial contracts with banks earlier this year, some council members turned to an unusual corner for financial advice: labor unions.

headline.main: Unions Make Strides as They Attack Banks

docs.abstract: Unions have criticized Wall Street before. But their attacks have taken on a new shape, both in ferocity and style, over the last 18 months, ever since the federal government doled out billions of dollars in bank bailouts. Labor leaders say the fortunes of banks and unions are linked more than people realize.
